entry.title: Combined summary - Drivechain RfD -- Follow Up
entry.summary: In an email exchange between Greg Slepak and Paul Sztorc, the Drivechain project is discussed and broken down into four modes of use. Concerns are raised about the possibility of miners stealing funds in Drivechain, which Paul refutes by explaining that miners cannot steal funds due to an automatic enforcement policy present in all full nodes. However, he acknowledges that users can choose to place their BTC at the mercy of miners in creative ways, similar to P2SH. The discussion also covers the difference between invalid transactions and withdrawals, and the significance of soft fork rules being followed. The context discusses the concept of a proof-of-burn sidechain, which is described as the ultimate two-way peg where users would tolerate depreciation for the purpose of having a cheap and secure way of transacting using a two-way pegged chain that isn't controlled by miners. The conversation also touches on the correlation between the security of a network and its total economic value, as well as the potential issue of Bitcoin miners choosing to mine both/all chains, which could consume more resources without contributing to a higher hashrate.The email thread in the context discusses the security of WT^ transactions in comparison to P2SH and SegWit transactions. The author argues that if the security of WT^ transactions could be improved to match that of P2SH and SegWit transactions, they would have fewer objections. However, they express doubt that this is possible.The conversation discusses the Drivechain specification and the different types of users it involves. There are four modes of use: [DC#0] for those who do not upgrade their Bitcoin software but experience the effects of new rules which miners add, [DC#1] for those who always upgrade to the latest version of the Bitcoin software with no interest in running or using sidechains, [DC#2] for those who upgrade to the latest Bitcoin version and also become full nodes of one or more sidechains but never actually use them, and [DC#3] for those who actively move money to and from sidechains after upgrading their software and running full nodes. The email conversations in the context provide a comprehensive look at the complexities and challenges associated with implementing a Drivechain system, with different perspectives and opinions from experts and stakeholders in the Bitcoin community.The discussion revolves around the implementation of Drivechain, a sidechain that allows for experimentation and innovation while being secured by the Bitcoin network. The participants discuss the potential risks and benefits of implementing Drivechain, including miner control and power over sidechain coins, security of the mining network, theft models, and mining centralization. They also explore various scenarios and weigh the pros and cons of using merged mining versus different POW for the sidechain. There are concerns about limiting user choice and reducing options from any trustworthy exchange to a single mining cartel under the control of a single set of laws. The conversation also discusses the different modes of use in Drivechain and the waiting period required to ensure the same WT^ is in both the Bitcoin coinbase and the sidechain header.The email conversation discusses the technical details of the Drivechain project and its potential implications. The disagreement between Greg Slepak and CryptAxe is about step 4 in the Drivechain specification, which suggests a waiting period for everyone to ensure that the same WT^ is in both the Bitcoin coinbase and the Sidechain header. Paul Sztorc seeks feedback on his project and introduces the concept of "Blind Merged Mining" to allow SHA256^2 miners to merge-mine these "drivechains." Drivechain is a sidechain enabling technology that seeks to plug many blockchains into the main chain, theoretically putting an end to the scalability debate forever. However, the implementation of Drivechain comes with several consequences. One of these is centralization of the Bitcoin network, allowing a 51% coalition or the government behind it to financially profit by confiscating coins. Additionally, it limits user choice of custodians, from any trustworthy exchange down to a single mining cartel under a single set of laws.The email conversations on the Bitcoin-dev mailing list revolve around the concept of sidechains, their potential implementation, and the implications for different groups involved in the mining process. The discussion covers topics such as proof-of-burn sidechains, UTXO commitments, and blind merged mining, with participants debating the security and economic value of each method. Concerns are raised regarding miner control over sidechain coins and the potential for mining centralization, with some advocating for merged mining instead of implementing a separate POW for drivechains. There are also concerns about limiting user choice when it comes to selecting a custodian for their bitcoins and the ecological impact of exchanges compared to sidechains. Overall, the conversation highlights the importance of ensuring that any changes made to the bitcoin network do not compromise its security and integrity.In the world of cryptocurrency, there is a new proposal being put forth by developer Paul Sztorc.
